Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2023.06.22]FI of main into dev for NuGetGallery" (#9528) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Merged pull request "Fix user credential result on admin panel" (#9524) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

problem: `IsAADorMACredential` is not assigned. 

Fix: check if credential is AAD or MA, then assign `IsAADorMACredential = true`, otherwise false

Test: Tested in dev environment

Addresses: https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4904

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Updating NuGet.Protocol version." (#9526) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "Updating NuGet.Protocol version." (#9526) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Restore task dumps stack because TaskCanceledException should be OperationCanceledException" (#12700) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Moving from https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/issues/7145

The RestoreTask tries to account for a cancellation token, but in its catch for it, it checks for a TaskCanceledException instead of an OperationCanceledException.

This [catch](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/f24bad0668193ce21a1db8cabd1ce95ba509c7f0/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Build.Tasks/RestoreTask.cs#L102) should be for OperationCanceledException thrown [here](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/6488c1a7913eb978fd7f667bbde4fa7e25821064/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Build.Tasks/BuildTasksUtility.cs#L266).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget package API appears to be broken" (#12699) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

Other/NA

### Current Behavior

None of the samples for https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/registration-base-url-resource work.
Quering a package like this: https://github.com/taori/NugetUnlister/blob/master/src/NugetUnlister/Helpers/PackageHelper.cs does not appear to work anymore either.

I am getting this error now:
![grafik](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/5545184/2c7ba107-e638-45e0-966c-aefb9b358155)


### Desired Behavior

It would be good if package querying kept working

### Additional Context

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Pack] Warning NU5100 “the assembly 'Package1.1.0.0.nupkg\lib\net481\Package1.dll' is not inside the 'lib' folder” shows incorrectly while the dll file is already inside the 'lib' folder" (#12624) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.7.0.51

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Steps:
1. Open VS and create a C# Class Library (.Net Framework 4.8.1) project. 
2. Build the solution and make sure compilation succeeds. 
3. Open “Developer Command Prompt”, cd to Package1 project path and execute `nuget spec`.
4. Execute command `nuget pack Package001.csproj `and make sure the “Package1.1.0.0.nupkg” is packed successfully.
5. Change the “Package1.1.0.0.nupkg” file extension to “Package1.1.0.0.nupkg.zip” and click “Extract All” context menu.
6. Execute command `nuget pack Package001.nuspec -OutputDirectory C:\Users\v-luzh\Desktop\OtherPath -version 3.0.0`.
#### Expected:
The lase warning NU5100 “the assembly 'Package1.1.0.0.nupkg\lib\net481\Package1.dll' is not inside the 'lib' folder” should not show.
#### Actual:
Warning NU5100 “the assembly 'Package1.1.0.0.nupkg\lib\net481\Package1.dll' is not inside the 'lib' folder” shows incorrectly while the dll file is inside the 'lib' folder as below.
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/20632625/588feec5-2111-4447-ba99-6da134d4455e)
#### Note:
1.The warning still repro after placing the Package1.dll file inside a framework-specific folder under a lib folder as the “solution” said in the [Doc](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/errors-and-warnings/nu5100) file as below.
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/20632625/5f235f10-e242-4a18-8c81-eb3bb3d3ac42)
2.It is not a regreasion since it reproes from the beginning.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Audit security vulnerabilities without adding nuget.org as package source " (#12698) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Starting with .NET 8, `dotnet restore` can warn about security vulnerabilities in referenced packages.
[According to the docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-restore#audit-for-security-vulnerabilities) this will only work when adding nuget.org as a package source.

> Additionally, to retrieve the known vulnerability dataset, ensure that you have the NuGet.org central registry defined as one of your package sources:

Please make it possible to use the security audit feature of `dotnet restore` without having to add nuget.org as a package source. Nuget.org should not implicitly become a package source but just the source for the known vulnerability dataset.

### Additional Context and Details

The company I work for maintains their own feed which contains a curated list of packages mirrored from nuget.org that are safe/allowed to be use in the company. The direct use of nuget.org as a package source is prohibited.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Perf: ContentFileUtils should cache/reuse virtual file instances" (#12696) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

all

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

This codepath is used when restoring PackageReference projects with packages that have `contentFiles/`. Therefore, restore performance could be improved.

Note, this will be less beneficial if the following PR and issues are fixed:
* https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/5231
* https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12695

Currently, when ContentFileUtils is trying to [match `<contentFiles>` entries in the nuspec to `contentFiles/` files in the zip](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/4b6a87bfe90d247f961eba41d63dbf418a56fdcc/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/RestoreCommand/ContentFiles/ContentFileUtils.cs#L104-L148), it has a nested loop, and creates a new `VirtualFileProvider` (will soon change to `SingleFileProvider`) within the inner loop. This means when there are 10 patterns in the nuspec, each file in the zip will have a provider created for it 10 times. If there are 20 files, then that's 200 provider objects created to match these 20 files.

Using [NuGet Insights](https://github.com/NuGet/Insights), I see that of packages that have any `<contentFiles>` with a `*` in their nuspec, the average is 1.2 entries and the max is 21 entries. However, only 143 packages contain more than 1 `<contentFiles>` pattern in their nuspec, and of those only 3 packages have over 1 million downloads. Although one of them is marked is marked as deprecated. So, overall, it's hard to say whether implementing this will actually have a meaningful impact. The `SingleFileProvider` might actually be better for most packages, since few packages use file globbing with more than 1 pattern.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Perf: ContentFileUtils uses expensive file globbing when not needed" (#12695) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

all

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

This codepath is used when restoring projects using PackageReference, and uses packages that contain `contentFiles/`. Therefore, restore performance could be improved.

When a package contains `contentFiles/`, and the project uses PackageReference, `ContentFileUtils.cs` is used to match the files in the zip, to metadata in the `.nuspec`. This code currently [always uses a file globbing API to do the match](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/4b6a87bfe90d247f961eba41d63dbf418a56fdcc/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/RestoreCommand/ContentFiles/ContentFileUtils.cs#L104-L148). However, using [NuGet Insights](https://github.com/NuGet/Insights), we can see that most packages that have `contentFiles/` do not use `*` or `?` characters in the `.nuspec` `<contentFiles>` definitions.

Debugging restore with a suitable package, the way the NuGet uses the file globbing library, it will see a file `contentFiles/any/any/something.txt`, and a "pattern" `any/any/something.txt`, and the file globbing library will ask for the "root directory" (which in this case is `contentFiles/`, then ask if `contentFiles/` contains `any/`, then ask if `contentFiles/any/` contains `any/`, and finally if `contentFiles/any/any/` contains `something.txt`.

So, as we can see, there's a lot of unnecessary work that needs to be done because NuGet has a list of strings that represent the full path of all content files in the zip, and it's usually trying to match the substring following the `contentFiles/` prefix.

Therefore, I believe this could be implemented to be much higher performance, although there are some `/` vs `\` matching, and case sensitivity, issues that need to be accounted for.

Basically, do "simple" string matching when the nuspec's entry's include doesn't contain either `*`, or `?` (and maybe if there's also no `exclude`, but an exclude doesn't make sense on an exact filename). Only use the file globbing library when file globbing is actually needed.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

Chocolatey v2.0.0-alpha-20230124

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

[As per the NuGet V3 API specification](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/registration-base-url-resource), `RegistrationsBaseUrl`, `RegistrationsBaseUrl/3.0.0-beta` and `RegistrationsBaseUrl/3.0.0-rc` are all aliases for the same `@type`. However, if the server provides only one of them (e.g., `RegistrationsBaseUrl`), the client throws an ArgumentNullException.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
System.ArgumentNullException: Value cannot be null.
Parameter name: baseUrl
   at NuGet.Protocol.RegistrationResourceV3..ctor(IHttpSource client, Uri baseUrl)
   at NuGet.Protocol.RegistrationResourceV3Provider.<TryCreate>d__1.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.SourceRepository.<GetResourceAsync>d__16`1.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.SourceRepository.<GetResourceAsync>d__15`1.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.PackageMetadataResourceV3Provider.<TryCreate>d__1.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.SourceRepository.<GetResourceAsync>d__16`1.MoveNext()
   --- End of inner exception stack trace ---
   at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.ThrowIfExceptional(Boolean includeTaskCanceledExceptions)
   at System.Threading.Tasks.Task.Wait(Int32 millisecondsTimeout, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.SourceRepository.GetResource[T](CancellationToken token)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.SourceRepository.GetResource[T]()
   at chocolatey.infrastructure.app.nuget.NugetCommon.<GetRepositoryResource>d__7`1.MoveNext()
   at System.Collections.Generic.List`1..ctor(IEnumerable`1 collection)
   at System.Linq.Enumerable.ToList[TSource](IEnumerable`1 source)
   at chocolatey.infrastructure.app.services.NugetService.install_run(ChocolateyConfiguration config, Action`2 continueAction)
   at chocolatey.infrastructure.app.services.ChocolateyPackageService.perform_source_runner_function[T](ChocolateyConfiguration config, Func`2 function)
   at chocolatey.infrastructure.app.services.ChocolateyPackageService.install_run(ChocolateyConfiguration config)
   at chocolatey.infrastructure.app.runners.GenericRunner.run(ChocolateyConfiguration config, Container container, Boolean isConsole, Action`1 parseArgs)
   at chocolatey.infrastructure.app.runners.ConsoleApplication.run(String[] args, ChocolateyConfiguration config, Container container)
   at chocolatey.console.Program.Main(String[] args)
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "A Preview Restore failure doesn't stop the installation workflow (eg, license dialog still opens)" (#12690) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

N/A

### Worked before?

N/A

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

The `ResolvedAction` from preview restore contains a result which has a `Success` indicator.
When this `Success==false`, that information is lost as it's translated into higher level `ProjectAction` objects here:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/f1757fe7a9a3e178562518f4535f71348a117010/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.VisualStudio/Services/NuGetProjectManagerService.cs#L693-L694

I believe any preview restore failure should cause the PM UI to bail out as soon as it's discovered that the preview restore has failed. 
Currently, the workflow continues, prompting the customer to agree to a license (for the top-level package being installed, if applicable), and other prompts, before eventually replaying all errors from the preview restore.

1. Open PM UI and prepare to perform a package installation. A package which requires license acceptance will make it easier to see the effect.
2. Configure your project such that a restore error will occur.
3. Perform the installation
4. Observe a License Acceptance dialog appears.
5. Accept the license
6. Observe that Restore errors are shown.

The errors are shown during the execution of the restore here: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/f1757fe7a9a3e178562518f4535f71348a117010/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/Actions/UIActionEngine.cs#L471
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/49205731/758539e1-8b6a-4a3a-99c6-820eb721d57c)


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ContentItemCollection.FindBestItemGroup boxing enumerator" (#12689) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability" (#69) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET and NuGet on Linux. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET 7.0 and NuGet(nuget.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement) where a potential race condition that can lead to a symlink attack on Linux. Non-Linux platforms are not affected. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12653 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software This issue only affects Linux systems. ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.6.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.5.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.4.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.3.2 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.2.3 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.0.4 version or earlier. [GitHub Advisory](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/security/advisories/GHSA-6qmf-mmc7-6c2p) ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET SDK 7.0.106 or earlier, or 7.0.303 or earlier - Any .NET SDK 6.0.117 or earlier, or 6.0.312 or earlier, or 6.0.409 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet package or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.PackageManagement versions). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.6.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.6.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.6.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.5.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.5.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.5.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.4.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.4.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.4.2/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.3.2 or lower, you should download and install 6.3.3 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.3.3/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.3 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.4 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.4/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.4 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.5/nuget.exe. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` - If you're using .NET 7.0, you should download and install Runtime 7.0.7 or SDK 7.0.107 or SDK 7.0.304 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/7.0. - If you're using .NET 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.18 or SDK 6.0.118 or SDK 6.0.312 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at . ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client . The Announcements repo will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### Acknowledgements [Kalle Niemitalo](https://github.com/KalleOlaviNiemitalo) ### External Links [CVE 2023-29337](https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2023-29337) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 13, 2023): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2023-06-13_
